Correct me if I'm wrong - but shouldn't it take 750MB to store the human genome, not 1.5GB?
Adenine (A) pairs with thymine (T) and cytosine (C) pairs with guanine (G), and they can form A-T, T-A, C-G, and G-C bonds.

Given this restriction, we can represent pairs as bits:

A-T - 00
T-A - 01
C-G - 10
G-C - 11

The human genome consists of roughly 3 billion of these pairs, and one byte (8 bits) can represent 4 pairs, thus - the entire human genome can be expressed in about 750 megabytes of data.

Chomsky would say that what you're referring to as the cognitive capacity is precisely "language" i.e. the language capacity ("mental organ" is a term he uses, to emphasize it as a preprogrammed biological function rather than some kind of arbitrary social construct), and that English, Mandarin etc. are simply specific languages, or different (at a surface level) modes of engaging in the same capacity. Since language is primarily a system of thought, and processing written or spoken information necessarily uses that system, it makes sense to focus (like you do) on that as the bottleneck for processing information delivered in that mode (spoken, written, signed, whatever), although I'm not sure you're justified in assuming (or perhaps implying) that the speed at which we are able to process information in the form of language tells us anything about the speed at which we are able to process information through other cognitive capacities (like extracting information from visual images, to name one).

To give you another idea of the amount of information in something, if you wanted to store every possible 16 bits per color channel (48 bits per pixel) 4K image possible, everything from random noise to every real photo of you and every conceivable "deep fake" as well, as well as everyone else and everywhere, you would need 48 to the power of (3840*2160) bits of storage, which comes out to 2.1 times 10 to the 13,944,887 bits (21 with 13,944,886 zeroes after it). In Terabytes, it's 2.4 times 10 to the 13,944,874. On the bright side you'll only need at most 398,131,200 bits to address each image individually, or about as much information as is in a single 16 bit per channel 4K image. 👌😂

English is a stress-timed language. Stressed syllables are longer, louder and higher-pitched. Unstressed syllables are weakened, so shorter, quieter and lower-pitched. Spanish is a syllable-timed language - the difference in length, loudness and pitch between stressed syllables and unstressed syllables is much less significant than in English. I'm not sure whether Spanish uses more syllables to express the same information as English (it's possible because of the morphology - e.g. verb endings) but the main difference is that English weakens most of its syllables (but doesn't eliminate them completely) and Spanish doesn't.

Can it make sense to talk about splitting the bit? (Like splitting the atom, but with atoms of information.)

A bit describes the state of something that's definitely in one or the other of two states. But word-salad purportedly based on quantum mechanics says that things aren't in definite either-or states. They're in superpositions of states. They do stuff that seems like spooky actions at a distance.

Normally, we describe this sort of thing by giving a detailed description of a system, involving many, many bits of information. But a whole lot of talk about quantum mechanics comes out as word-salad, in ways that sound as though maybe we're going at either-or states of a system in the wrong way. Maybe there's something going on where every yes/no answer has to be made of two parts, a heads/tails answer-part and a heads-means-yes/tails-means-yes answer-part.

So yeah, we know that I can't make sense while trying to talk about splitting the bit. But that might merely be because I'm not all that good at it, and the people who would be good at it haven't tried yet. Or of course, it might be because the whole idea is nonsensical. But how can we know which?

There's an important caveat to what Derek says around 3:20. You don't actually share 99.9% of your DNA with all other life forms, but you do with ANY other life form. Compare any two people, and their DNA is almost identical, but the differences that distinguish James from Brandon are NOT the same differences that distinguish James from Mary, even though those two are also nearly identical. This is how genetic diseases happen. Most people have A where a small group of people has B, but all those A and B people might have C where another small group has D. (B causes one genetic disease and D causes another.) There isn't just a "grab bag" section of the DNA code in which all these diseases appear; they're spread out randomly among the "normal" lines of code. If you compare one organism with another, then they're 99.9% the same. But if you then compare a third organism to those two, the DNA shared by all three drops well below 99.9%. Add a fourth, and the DNA shared by all becomes an even smaller percentage of the total. If you keep adding organisms, the total amount shared is almost nothing.

Edit: I thought of a better way to explain this. Imagine a sequence of a hundred letters where 99 of them are x and one of them is y. You could have, for instance, a y followed by 99 x's, or 99 x's followed by a y, or xy followed by 98 x's, etc. If you compare any two of them and ask the question, "How many x's are in the same place?" the answer is always "98." (If you compare the first two, then the middle 98 x's are the same.) But add a third sequence for comparison, and only 97 x's are in the same place for all three. If you add all one hundred possible sequences together and ask the same question, then NONE of them have even a single x that is in the same place as all the others, even though it's still true that any two sequences accord with 98 of their hundred x's. DNA is like that.

1. Most (if not all) DNA strands in your body are slightly different from the rest of them, due to damaging factors(tiny fractions of a percentage, but the combined effect of this differentiation may not be trivial).
2. More accurately, the information in all 23 chromosomes is closer to 1.6 GB. (6,469.66 megabasepairs * 2 bit = 1.617415 GB)
2. Instead of actually storing 40 trillion cells worth of DNA strands (with 1.61GB of information each), you could compress the information in a number of ways:
a) Reduce by eliminating the non-coding DNA in all but the first sequence, like: BASE_SEQ + n"variable parts". Since 98% is non-coding, this means 32MB or so for the variable parts.
b) Reduce the number of different sequences with an algorithm not that much different from the Dijkstra algorithm.
c) subsequent compression methods

You need three binary digits to encode all the possible different results of a dice roll. However, you don't need three bits of information to determine the result. You actually need log2 of 6 = 2.584963. You need three bits to choose between 8 equally probable outcomes.
Same thing for the alphabet: you need 5 binary digits to represent each letter, but you only need log2 of 26 = 4.70044 bits of information to know what letter was picked at random.
Binary digits are NOT the same thing as bits. A binary digit is the value of a binary variable; a bit of information is the quantity of information you need to choose between two equally probable outcomes. A single binary digit will give you precisely one bit of information if it discriminates between two equally probable outcomes.

Of course, DNA is a part of the story, not the whole story. Let us remember that two animals as different as a butterfly and its caterpillar have exactly the same DNA. Everything depends on what is repressed and what is "derepressed" :-)

However, there's a few things to consider. We encode information in bits but bits have no inherent meaning. For us to extract the information we actually need to know a bit more: the algorithm with which we can decode the information again. After all: 1010 is just 4 bits. You don't know what it is. Is it a 4bit number, is it two 2bit numbers, is it part of an image? We don't know. That's not encoded within the bits. With shanon we can calculate how many bits we need to encode a symbol. However, it's up to us to define what exactly a symbol is. If you treat combinations of letters as symbols then you will be able to compress even further. In an image uniform (colour) areas have less entropy but saying it doesn't contain much information depends on "information to whom". After all, all these pixels carry the same amount of information in the sense that you know that there's a uniform area in that image. In image compression regions of pixels of almost the same color are compressed as regions of exactly the same color because the human eye doesn't notice it so we could say that these pixels contain less information to us. But do they? You can even compress huge random sequences if you can find a seed and a PRNG that generates this sequence meaning that the sequence wouldn't contain as much information as once thought. I find it hard to come up with an exact definition for "information". 0000 contains as much information as 0101 even though the first one can be compressed better but the amount of information in it is the same. The entropy is different, but the amount of information is the same.

On some level, there will always be expressions in language that depend upon some understanding of the culture - things that don't translate readily. As a native English speaker who has also been speaking Spanish for most of my life, there are definitely concepts that don't translate well between the two. I'm talking about the order of a sequence or data string. First, you mentioned ASCII code as a way to computationally express human language, and while it's true there's a certain load of information associated to each letter (that is, one byte), the output also depends on the order of these elements. It becomes obvious that the order of the elements in a string is key to the total information load if you take anagrams into account: for example, "mutilate" and "ultimate" have exactly the same letters and even some of them are similarly ordered, but the change in the position of some of them yields two entirely different words.

Later, you mentioned DNA sequences as a 2-bit resolution sequence, but anyone who has taken biology on high school knows that the key feature of DNA sequences are the transcription and translation of large sequences into similarly ordered sequences which, at a later stage of synthesis, become entangled in a network of weak interactions that depend on the sequence of the peptide, and not just the elements conforming it. Blah, blah, blah, gibberish. What I mean to say is that you implied that the elements conforming language (either letters, as seen in ASCII or DNA sequences; or syllables, of which I'm not going to talk, but also were mentioned to have a certain load of information) contain information, but organization of these elements contains just as much information. Why is it not reflected on, let's say, larger memory requirements for computers processing text? Because the order of the binary digits reflects the order of the characters, therefore making it unnecessary to input more data. And yet, there's a certain load of information contained in the order of each data string.

Sorry for the long post, anyway. I thought you might find it interesting ;) What are your thoughts on this subject?

You say "The smallest amount of information that you can have is the answer to a yes no question", by which you mean one bit. Is that really true, though? The binary entropy function shows that if you have a coin that isn't fair, one toss of that coin won't give you one bit of information. For a coin which lands on heads 70% of the time, for example, the information contained in a toss is

-0.7 log 0.7 - 0.3 log 0.3 = 0.88

bits of information (where log is the logarithm to the base 2). I suggest that the smallest amount of information you can have is 0 bits. The smallest non-zero amount of information you can have is not defined. (That is, if I remember correctly that there is no real number that is larger to zero but closer to it than any other real number.)

binary is not the lowest amount of information- Unary is;  1 meaning that something exists and null meaning that it does not; different from 1 and 0  (binary).

Null means there is no container to store information as there is no information to store. 1 means that the value is present and so is the ability to store the information.

In binary you can ask true/false questions; in unary you can ask exist/not exist questions.

Binary: This a comment on youtube. Answer: 1
Binary: I'm made of gold. Answer: 0
Unary: There is gold somewhere on Earth. Response: 1
Unary: There is a pile of gold in my house. Response:

If Binary truly were the form of information store used by the universe, then all the things that don't exist would have a value of 0 - meaning that something is storing that information; if Unary is being used then there is no need to keep track of what doesn't exist.

Okay but the Spanish part seems misleading. I am a native Spanish speaker from Mexico and I speak slow relative to people from other parts of Mexico and people from Spain. Just like how people from England sometimes seem to speak faster than Americans. This is more of a regionalism than anything else. It probably has more to do with elision than "redundancy" of the language. As a Mexican, I have difficulty understanding people from  Andalusia, as they seem to speak faster than me, but that doesn't mean that they are being redundant. I can't think of a single spoken or written sentence in Spanish where information in it is redundant, it all has meaning if it is said or written correctly. In fact, if anything, elision probably originated as the "lazy", "wrong" or "incorrect" (colloquial) way of talking as far as I know, but it came to be accepted over time, however that doesn't mean that actually enunciating each syllable creates "redundant" information (at least in Spanish).

If you are referring to the conjugation of nouns and verbs in Spanish, well quite frankly, that isn't really redundant either... In fact it allows Spanish speakers to express in ways which are virtually impossible in English.

For example, in football ("soccer") you will hear commentators use expressions like "Zapatazo". This is virtually impossible to translate to English in a single word. So if anything, English is more redundant? Either way, this type of analysis is irrelevant if coming from a person who is evidently not even bilingual...

Problem with the "you could, in principle, figure out exactly what we said here."

My specific issue has to do with the speed of light.

Let's say that a particle and it's anti-particle are floating in space and they collide and annihilate. Unless the resulting pair of gamma rays collide with something, there will be no way to detect what happened to them within the universe.

And if they don't hit the particles of a nearby galaxy, the travel time for them to hit far away ones is such that the universe will expand sufficiently as to maintain an increasing distances between the gamma rays and their would-be destination of a receding galaxy.

Eventually, in the far far far FAR future, the particle density where the gamma ray is will be such that no more particles will ever be able to encounter it.

Thus, any light that goes out that far will become lost information, existing within it's own observable universe.

For that matter, even if it did actually reach said galaxy, it may reach it after it has escaped the observable universe containing the center of the collision. Nothing that the observer could do within the laws of physics would allow them to gain information from the receding galaxy about it being hit by the gamma ray.

Thus, the information and energy in those particles is effectively deleted from existence unless photons can somehow alter the course of another particle.

How many times did he roll the dice? Zero! it's much easier to spot at 0.25x speed.

Theoretically the probability is 6!/(6^6), or about 0.015 I'll explain...
To start off, I can pick any number, since eventually I will be rolling all six. That's a probability of 6*(1/6), or 1.
Next, the chance I get any number except the one I just rolled. That's a bit more tricky. Of my six cases, five of them are acceptable. (We're only measuring the acceptable cases here!) The probability of getting any number on the dye is still 1/6. So we would find this out with 5*((1/6)). Make sense?
Now the same logic works for 4,3,2, and 1.
Multiplying by 1/6 is the same as dividing by 6, and since we're doing that six times, we can abbreviate 6*6*6*6*6*6 as 6^6.
Multiplying 6*5*4*3*2*1 can be abbreviated with a factorial, so it's "6!".

This leaves us with 6!/(6^6).
'Fun' note: order doesn't matter here. I could roll 4,5,1,6,2,3 or anything else that gives me a single dye of each number. If order did matter, the probability would be as simple as (1/6)^6. If we reverse engineered the problem from the answer, we would know order didn't matter because of the 6!.

I've also been thinking whether QM really allows to reconstruct an earlier state from the current one. The truth is that I haven't seen this calculation being done.
First of all, since we do not know the initial state, we cannot use the Lagrangian formulation - so we will have to stick with the Hamiltonian.

Now there are two problems; first, is the measurement problem - not treated by theory - and secondly can we really calculate the earlier state?

For the measurement problem we can postulate the following; suppose that we somehow obtain information about the wavefunction of a big chunk of the world and that we can from that calculate the wavefunction at an earlier time. But what would happen if there has been measurements (whose outcomes we do not know) between the time we do know and the time we want to arrive at? We will need a theory that could deal with measurement. And in a dense world, such as the one we live in, measurements are performed frequently, so objects appear to have definite paths. There is an analogy between this situation and particles in cloud chambers where particles appear to have definite paths. However, can we always predict their backwards motion indefinitely? That's an open question.

Secondly, we can note that as a 2nd order pde, the time-dependent Schroedinger equation is similar to the equation describing heat dissipation and diffusion processes (only with complex coefficients) - and it is known that we cannot reconstruct an earlier state from a later state for these systems; this is because many different initial conditions will evolve towards the same final state; and so they eventually become indistinguishable. This also has parallels with entropy (that is in the case of heat dissipation and diffusion processes).

So it is not clear that we can reconstruct an earlier state from the current one, even in principle. Unless we work with some classical approximation.

Simple example: Information on a hard drive (zeros or ones) is represented by the spins (down or up) of groups of atoms. If you heat the disk beyond a certain temperature (the Curie temperature) the spins will begin to flip randomly and the information will be lost.

My understanding is that quantum physics pretty much put an end to the deterministic world view. For example, if you observe a gamma ray leaving an atomic nucleus,is this the result of a gamma ray that hit the atom being re-emitted? The emission from an atomic fusion reaction? If it's from fusion, how do you know what particles were involved and what their velocities were? On another note, how do you deal with the contents of black holes that are unobservable and may not even observe the same physical laws?

Basically, if you're told the sum of two numbers is 4, you don't know if those numbers were 2+2, 1+3, 2^0.5+(4-2^0.5) or any of many other possibilities. In the same way, the physical world encodes many possible prior states - we can get an estimate of what things were once like, but we can never determine the entire story, even with complete information.

Also - the 1.5GB estimate ignores that males have another hundred million or so gametes, each with a randomised half of their genome. Adding these in would contribute another 300MB or so to the information total. (Mitochondrian DNA adds a small amount as well, but it would get buried in rounding errors.)

And of course, we're ignoring the information content of the brain here. I've seen a lowball estimate of 2.5 petabytes for that...

The end of the video can be true to an extent (theoretically). It requires for us to know the physics and chemistry of our environment so well, however, that we would be able to decode how a molecule was affected by, say, a particular sound-wave. However, because each molecules in our environment are bombarded by such waves endlessly, and are, at the same time going through other permutations, using such information would have to be under very controlling circumstances. That said, such a method is very probably a future step in memory storage, albeit extremely far away. First we must find an element that has, or can have no impermeability in some state, find a way to keep it in that state, and find a way to change miniscule parts of it while retaining the state. This will likely be after having encoded biology, and, of course, our present memory state after it is refined to a molecular level which it is close to).

It's an interesting question about whether digital information & data is actually a real, tangible physical object. Information has always be inseparable from its mode of delivery & storage, like the words in a book or the grooves in a wax cylinder or vinyl record. However, the 0s & 1 of digital data seems more disconnected from the physical medium, such as the magnetic medium in HDDs, floppy disks and tape drives, or the NAND Flash in SSDs, memory cards, and USB Thumb drives, that they are stored, even more so when those 0s & 1s are streamed over a network or store data in the cloud.

I don't think Spanish is more redundant (yep, I speak Spanish, and Galician which have a common root which is Latin), it's just that Spanish has longer words, but that does not mean that the "excess" of letters/syllables are redundant, at least not in the way information is send through, say, the internet or stored in a c.d. which, if I remember correctly, cd's actually store about 2.1 GB of information due to redundancy and error-correcting techniques. Something similar happens to DVD's of course.

The idea of using scientific observation and calculation of some kind to trace all physical processes backwards is an old western thought prominent in the notion of determinism. In the thought, if a sufficient amount of initial conditions were known, tracing back the paths and actions and reactions of all physical phenomena would be possible, given an understanding of the natural laws they follow. Afterward, all future events could be predicted to the specificity of the initial conditions known by using the same laws and the now more contemporary initial conditions.

I thought that when things mix, 'unscrambling' that information is essentially impossible, i.e. you can have many initial states that will give rise to the final state that you measure.

So it can't be done if you measure the 'macroscopic' state, especially if the system has evolved into the steady state. Perhaps it might be possible if you could measure the positions and momenta of all particles exactly and then reverse the direction of the momenta... of course you will have to solve the n-body problem (on a side note, I believe that it has been solved, but the calculation required to get any useful predictions is more expensive than the numerical simulations needed to obtain the same accuracy(?)). And measure positions and momenta without perturbing the system. And violate locality of special relativity (assuming that you caused the event), since you will have to catch up with any photons, or other massless particles, emitted by the initial event. So you could recover the information, in principle, only if the particles behave more-or-less classically and non-relativistically.

I think I'd like to respectfully disagree with the end conclusion of this video.  I don't think that, given a real system in this universe as we understand it now and its parts, we could trace back all of the information that has passed through it.

I understand the sentiment, but I feel as though eventually some ambiguity would begin to arise.  If you take for example, Godel's notation, it uses all prime numbers to create very large numbers that are unique products that can only be traced back to one thing.

However, in real life we have situations that can arise from multiple beginnings.  Say, for an example off the top of my head, the system we were looking at was a line with a wave in it.  This wave was created by vibrations in the surface.  If we were lucky, the ripples may be just so that they all did not overlap with each other, but say we had two waves with the same origin point, the same frequency, and different amplitudes.  You would get a constructive wave that would appear to be one wave that started at one point, but the actual information put into the system would have been different than what you started with.

Is this small example true for larger systems?  I don't know.  It's midnight and I'm up watching this, but I have done physics at university for some time now, and the conclusion seems a touch off.  If you have a reply @Veritasium or anyone else for that matter, I'd love to hear it.

7-bit ASCII was used for various things, including modem communication before there was hardware error correction.  The 8th bit of the byte sent was used for parity, to help tell if the data came through properly (which was still no guarantee).  It was really popular for just generic text terminals, since they only needed to display readable text.  PCs then helped standardize the use of 8-bit ASCII since they had all of those extended ASCII characters which could be used for basic artwork and text-based GUIs, which you've probably seen in ASCII/ANSI artwork at some point.  But inside of every serial port/modem in computers today is still the ability to output 7-bit data with a parity bit.  

There's actually quite a lot of backwards compatibility in your PC, including the fact that it boots up in 16-bit mode and can still run the same DOS from 30 years ago, but that's a story for another day!

I once read an interesting approach to quantifying information: In this approach, information of a message M was defined as -ln(P(M)), where P(M) is the probability of the message M occurring. Hence, the message "Dog bites Earthling" has less information than "Earthling bites dog", because its probability is higher. Also, the message "Earthling bites dog" has more information in a serious newspaper, rather than a yellow press newspaper. This approach is of course based on the earthlings' binary thinking, their idea that everything has a probability [in other words, can be projected onto the true-false edge of the triangle of ternary alien logic]. But it's quite consistent. For example, the information of the combination of two independent messages is the sum of the two informations.

A couple of thoughts:

The yes/no info that answers the question, "Have you seen Frozen" may be encoded in a single bit, except that bit contains no information at all, absent its context, which would take considerably more information to establish... in fact, establishing that context inevitably connects that bit of information to every other bit in the universe.

By no means can you figure out what was said in a room five minutes ago by the information content of the rest of the atoms in that room, because their reaction to the sound vibrations five minutes ago depends on a the state of the system at that time. First of all, the state at that time is dependent on other physical processes going back to the big bang. Secondly, even if you could specify the state of the system at the time of the talk, the non-linearity of the processes governing the propagation of those sound waves upon reflection with real surfaces means that it would be impossible to reconstruct the speech after the first couple of echos, much less five minutes later.

I'm not sure that information can be casually dismissed as materialist at all, much less assert that it can be understood in the context of the four forces with some computation needed.

@Veritasium The unqueness of a person could not be stored on a floppy disk. The information in DNA is not just whether it is 1,2,3 or 4, but also it's position. IF you take all the unique bits out and stung them together, you've actually lost a lot of information. This is the same reason why patches/diffs of computer code are bigger than the actual number of bytes being changed by the patch set. All those extra bytes encode the offsets and some checking to make sure that each bit goes in the right place.

So for non-contigious DNA where no half-nibble delta appears next to another one. We'd need 33 bits per 2 bit delta. Giving us 27MB requirement with no checksums and a really weird non-byte boundry storage mechanism. And that's assuming no insertions or deletions, just chages. We'd need more bytes to store what needs to be done if we want to actually create a working mechanism.
